links.title: How China steals U.S. secrets
links.description: China wants to steal U.S. secrets and is very good at doing so. "China, from a counterintelligence perspective, represents the broadest, most pervasive, most threatening challenge we face as a country," FBI Director Christopher Wray told the Aspen Security Forum in July. messages.body: $AAPL $SPY $QQQ https://finance.yahoo.com/news/heres-much-warren-buffet-made-massive-investment-apple-223511846.html

links.title: Here's how much Warren Buffett has made from his massive investment in Apple
links.description: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway ( BRK-A, BRK-B) bet big on Apple and is winning big, too. During the second quarter ended June 30, Berkshire Hathaway added nearly 12.4 million shares of Apple ( AAPL), bringing its already massive stake in the iPhone maker to nearly 251.96 million shares, a position valued at over $52.8 billion when using Tuesday's market close of $209.75.

links.title: US and China plot roadmap to resolve trade dispute
links.description: CNBC's Dominic Chu reports that according to Dow Jones, the U.S. and China are planning a way to resolve the trade dispute between the two countries, including a high-level meeting in November.

links.title: Above The 40 - Another Picture-Perfect Rebound Ends Stretched Conditions
links.description: The recovery from the February swoon has been full of nearly predictable bounces: whether it was oversold trading conditions or support at the 50 and 200-day moving averages (DMAs). Such moves are the hallmarks of a bull market. At some point these bounces will not work. Last week was not that week.

messages.body: Judge upholds delay of anti-segregation housing rule $AAPL #AAPL https://www.marketbeat.com/n/3960649/

links.title: Judge upholds delay of anti-segregation housing rule
links.description: WASHINGTON (AP) - A federal judge has upheld a decision by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to delay an Obama-era anti-discrimination rule. Chief Judge Beryl A. Howell of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on Friday threw out a lawsuit filed by a group of civil rights organizations challenging HUD's delay of the Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing rule.
